\sphinxAtStartPar
Adds a point\sphinxhyphen{}type layer to the builder.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Ideally the layer’s ‘data’ member should contain
lat/long columns or point like geometry column. If the geometry column
is present and contains no point like geometry, the geometry will be converted
into a bunch of points.

\index{adjust\_opacity() (geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method)@\spxentry{adjust\_opacity()}\spxextra{geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{builder:geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder.adjust_opacity}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{adjust\_opacity}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{alpha}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{Optional\DUrole{p}{{[}}float\DUrole{p}{{]}}} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Conforms the opacity of the color bar of the hexbin layer to an alpha value.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The alpha value can be passed in as a parameter, otherwise it is taken
from the marker.opacity property within the layer’s manager.

\index{apply\_to\_query() (geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method)@\spxentry{apply\_to\_query()}\spxextra{geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{builder:geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder.apply_to_query}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{apply\_to\_query}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{name}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{str}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{fn}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{*}\DUrole{n}{args}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{allow\_empty}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{bool} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{True}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{**}\DUrole{n}{kwargs}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Applies a function to the layers within a query.

For advanced users and not to be used carelessly.
The functions first argument must be the layer.

\sphinxAtStartPar

\index{clip\_layers() (geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method)@\spxentry{clip\_layers()}\spxextra{geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{builder:geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder.clip_layers}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{clip\_layers}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{clip}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{str}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{to}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{str}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{method}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{str} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{\textquotesingle{}sjoin\textquotesingle{}}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{reduce\_first}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{bool} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{True}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{operation}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{str} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{\textquotesingle{}intersects\textquotesingle{}}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Clips a query of layers to another layer.
this function is experimental and may not always work as intended

\sphinxAtStartPar
There are two methods for this clipping:
1) sjoin \sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{} Uses GeoPandas spatial join in order to clip geometries
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
that (intersect, are within, contain, etc.) the geometries
acting as the clip.
\end{quote}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{)}%
\setcounter{enumi}{1}
\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{gpd  \sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{}  Uses GeoPandas clip function in order to clip geometries}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
to the boundary of the geometries acting as the clip.

\end{description}

\end{enumerate}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{clip}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{GeoDataFrame}}) \textendash{} The query for the layers that are to be clipped to another

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{to}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{GeoDataFrame}}) \textendash{} The query for the layers that are to be used as the boundary

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{method}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The method to use when clipping, one of ‘sjoin’, ‘gpd’

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{reduce\_first}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} Determines whether the geometries acting as the clip should be reduced first or not

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{operation}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The operation to apply when using sjoin (spatial join operation)

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{finalize() (geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method)@\spxentry{finalize()}\spxextra{geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{builder:geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder.finalize}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{finalize}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{plot\_regions}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{bool} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{True}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{plot\_grids}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{bool} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{True}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{plot\_hexbin}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{bool} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{True}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{plot\_outlines}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{bool} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{True}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{plot\_points}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{bool} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{True}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{raise\_errors}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{bool} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{False}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Builds the final plot by adding traces in order.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Invokes the functions in the following order:
1) plot regions
2) plot grids
3) plot layer
4) plot outlines
5) plot points

\sphinxAtStartPar
In the future we should alter these functions to
allow trace order implementation.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{plot\_regions}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} Whether or not to plot region layers

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{plot\_grids}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} Whether or not to plot grid layers

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{plot\_hexbin}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} Whether or not to plot the hexbin layer

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{plot\_outlines}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} Whether or not to plot outline layers

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{plot\_points}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} Whether or not to plot point layers

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{raise\_errors}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} Whether or not to raise errors related to empty layer collections

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{logify\_scale() (geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method)@\spxentry{logify\_scale()}\spxextra{geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{builder:geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder.logify_scale}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{logify\_scale}}}{\emph{\DUrole{o}{**}\DUrole{n}{kwargs}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Makes the scale of the hexbin layers logarithmic.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function changes the tick values and tick text of the scale.
The numerical values on the scale are the exponent of the tick text,
i.e the text of 1 on the scale actually represents the value of zero,
and the text of 1000 on the scale actually represents the value of 3.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{kwargs}} ({\color{red}\bfseries{}**}kwargs) \textendash{} Keyword arguments to be passed into logify functions

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{output() (geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method)@\spxentry{output()}\spxextra{geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{builder:geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder.output}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{output}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{filepath}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{Optional\DUrole{p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p}{{]}}} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{clear\_figure}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{bool} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{False}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{crop\_output}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{bool} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{False}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{percent\_retain}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{keep\_original}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{bool} \DUrole{o}{=} \DUrole{default_value}{False}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{**}\DUrole{n}{kwargs}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Outputs the figure to a filepath.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The figure is output via Plotly’s write\_image() function.
Plotly’s Kaleido is required for this feature.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{clear\_figure}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} Whether or not to clear the figure after this operation

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{crop\_output}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} Whether or not to crop the output figure (requires that extension be pdf, PdfCropMargins must be installed)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{percent\_retain}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{float}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{, }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}) \textendash{} Percentage of margins to retain from crop (requires that extension be pdf, PdfCropMargins must be installed)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{keep\_original}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} Whether or not to keep the original figure (requires that extension be pdf, PdfCropMargins must be installed)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\index{search() (geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method)@\spxentry{search()}\spxextra{geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{builder:geohexviz.builder.PlotBuilder.search}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{search}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{query}\DUrole{p}{:} \DUrole{n}{str}}}{{ $\rightarrow$ Dict\DUrole{p}{{[}}str\DUrole{p}{, }Any\DUrole{p}{{]}}}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Query the builder for specific layer(s).

\sphinxAtStartPar
Each query argument should be formatted like:
\textless{}regions|grids|outlines|points|main|hexbin|all\textgreater{}
OR
\textless{}region|grid|outline|point\textgreater{}:\textless{}name\textgreater{}

\sphinxAtStartPar
And each query argument can be separated by the ‘+’ character.

\sphinxAtStartPar
External version.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar

\chapter{Further Information}
\label{\detokenize{index:further-information}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
GeoHexViz is a package for the simple and repeatable visualization of
hexagon\sphinxhyphen{}ally binned data sets.
The package’s main feature is a PlotBuilder class which utilizes tools
to hexagon\sphinxhyphen{}ally bin your dataset and then display it.


\section{Command Line / JSON Usage}
\label{\detokenize{index:command-line-json-usage}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GeoHexViz distribution includes a module that can allow the reading
of JSON files for quick and easy plots.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}main\PYGZus{}dataset\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}data\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZlt{}sample csv file\PYGZgt{}\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}hex\PYGZus{}resolution\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{4}
  \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{},}
  \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}output\PYGZus{}figure\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}filepath\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZlt{}sample filepath\PYGZgt{}\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}width\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{600}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}height\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+m+mi}{400}
  \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{},}
  \PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}display\PYGZus{}figure\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{true}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
running the JSON script will allow you to input a JSON file via command
line.

\sphinxAtStartPar
You may also use the functions that allow the executing of a JSON file
from a python module.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{scripts}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{geohexsimple}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{simple} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{run\PYGZus{}json}

\PYG{n}{run\PYGZus{}json}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZlt{}filepath here\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\section{Installation}
\label{\detokenize{index:installation}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
As of right now the GeoHexViz package can be cloned on GitHub, and
install by using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{setup.py}} file.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In the near future the package will be available via pip:
Use the package manager \sphinxhref{https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/}{pip} to install GeoHexViz.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
pip install geohexviz
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{Further Documentation}
\label{\detokenize{index:further-documentation}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
There is further documentation contained within the Reference Document
published alongside this software package, which is available \{HERE\}.
The official API documentation is also available \{HERE\}.


\section{Acknowledgements}
\label{\detokenize{index:acknowledgements}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Thank you to Nicholi Shiell for his input in testing, and providing
advice for the development of this package.


\section{Limitations}
\label{\detokenize{index:limitations}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This package uses GeoJSON format to plot data sets. With GeoJSON comes
difficulties when geometries cross the 180th meridian . The issue
appears to cause a color that bleeds through the entire plot and leaves
a hexagon empty. In the final plot, this issue may or may not appear as
it only occurs at certain angles of rotation. In this package a simple
solution to the problem is implemented, in the future it would be best
to provide a more robust solution. The solution that is used works
generally, however, when hexagons containing either the north or south
pole are present, the solution to the 180th meridian issue persists.
This pole issue can be seen below.

\sphinxAtStartPar
There also exists some issues with the generation of discrete color
scales under rare circumstances. These circumstances include generating
discrete color scales with not enough hues to fill the scale, and
generating diverging discrete colorscales with the center hue in a weird
position. These issues have been noted and will be fixed in the near
future.

\sphinxAtStartPar
There exists issues with the positioning and height of the color bar
with respect to the plot area of the figure. Although the user is
capable of altering the dimensions and positioning of the color bar,
this should be done automatically as it is a common feature of
publication quality choropleth maps.

\label{\detokenize{index:contributing}}

like to change.

\chapter{Indices and tables}
\label{\detokenize{index:indices-and-tables}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
